newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexican grain consumers seek import quotas - paper.
newsitem.headline: Mexican grain consumers seek import quotas - paper.

text.p: Mexican grain consumers, especially corn users, want the government to award tariff-free import quotas to maintain feed supplies, the daily Reforma said in its Thursday edition.
Carlos Sanchez Widman, of the National Association of Poultry Breeders, said consumers were now unable to buy the quality of grain needed for feedlots.
He said domestic corn supplies were dwindling and that part of the corn shortage problem was that for the first three months of the year no import quotas were awarded, Reforma said.
Mexico traditionally hands out import quotas of grains, mainly corn, as a top up measure for feed demands in any given crop year because domestic crops do not meet demands.

Mexican Agriculture Minister Francisco Labastida Ochoa told Reuters recently he expected grain imports to fall to 5-6 million tonnes this year from the 9.5 million tonnes in 1996 on the back of an improved domestic harvest.
